Changing spectrum of hemoptysis.  Underlying causes in 148 patients undergoing diagnostic flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopy.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

The patient's initial laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytes12,500/mm3
Hemoglobin10.5 g/dL
Platelets225,000/mm3
Creatinine1.2 mg/dL
International Normalized Ratio1.1

While in the emergency department, the patient has an episode of coughing and shortness of breath.  He brings up approximately 600 mL of blood.  His blood pressure is 105/61 mm Hg and pulse is 122/min.  He is intubated, and fresh blood fills the endotracheal tube.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has an episode of massive hemoptysis, defined as >600 mL of expectorated blood over a 24-hour period or a bleeding rate >100 mL/hour.  The greatest danger in massive hemoptysis is not exsanguination but asphyxiation due to the airway flooding with blood.  Initial management involves establishing an adequate patent airway, maintaining adequate ventilation and gas exchange, and ensuring hemodynamic stability.  The patient should be placed with the bleeding lung in the dependent position (lateral position) to avoid blood collection in the airways of the opposite lung.

Bronchoscopy is the initial procedure of choice in such patients as it can localize the bleeding site, provide suctioning ability to improve visualization, and include other therapeutic interventions (eg, balloon tamponade, electrocautery).

(Choice B)  High-resolution CT scan of the chest can be used in patients with mild-to-moderate hemoptysis to better visualize the underlying lung pathology.  However, this patient is actively bleeding and needs a therapeutic procedure first.

(Choice C)  Fresh frozen plasma should be given to patients with known or suspected coagulopathy (eg, International Normalized Ratio >1.5) as the cause of hemoptysis.  There is no such indication in this patient.

(Choice D)  Pulmonary arteriography should be performed when there is persistent bleeding and the initial bronchoscopy is unable to localize the source.  It can precisely identify the bleeding vessels and be used for therapeutic embolization to stop the bleeding.

(Choice E)  Urgent thoracotomy and surgical intervention are reserved for patients with unilateral bleeding who continue to bleed despite initial bronchoscopy and/or pulmonary artery embolization.

Educational objective:
Initial management in hemoptysis involves establishing adequate patent airway, maintaining adequate ventilation and gas exchange, and ensuring hemodynamic stability.  Patients should be placed with the bleeding lung in the dependent position (lateral position).  Bronchoscopy is the procedure of choice to identify the site and attempt early therapeutic intervention.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is hospitalized due to fever, chills, dysuria, flank pain, and lethargy.  Temperature is 39.8 C (103.6 F), blood pressure is 86/42 mm Hg, and pulse is 118/min.  Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present, and urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria.  Urine and blood cultures are obtained, and intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics are administered.  Due to persistent hypotension, the patient requires norepinephrine therapy and is admitted to the intensive care unit.  Two days later, the hypotension resolves, and the norepinephrine is tapered off.  The patient's fever gradually improves, and the antibiotics are adjusted based on culture and sensitivity results.  Repeat physical examination reveals discoloration in all the extremities as shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the findings seen in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus had acute pyelonephritis (eg, fever/chills, flank pain/costovertebral angle tenderness, pyuria/bacteriuria) complicated by septic shock.  A type of distributive shock, septic shock is characterized by peripheral vasodilation that can lead to profound hypotension.  As a result, vasopressors, which increase systemic vascular resistance, are often necessary following fluid resuscitation to restore adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP).

Norepinephrine, a first-line vasopressor for treatment of septic shock, acts on both alpha-1 and beta-1 adrenergic receptors, and its alpha-1 agonist properties produce potent vasoconstriction.  This vasoconstriction increases MAP to provide circulation to critical organs (eg, brain); however, it also decreases perfusion to peripheral structures such as the distal digits.  The resulting digital ischemia, which is typically bilateral and symmetric, can lead to tissue necrosis (eg, dry gangrene) if prolonged, as seen in this patient.

In a similar fashion, vasopressor-induced vasoconstriction can negatively impact the intestines (causing mesenteric ischemia) and/or kidneys (causing renal failure).

(Choice A)  Endocarditis can spread septic emboli throughout the body but would not be expected to symmetrically affect all the extremities.

(Choice B)  Some patients may form heparin-platelet factor 4 antibodies after receiving heparin, even at low doses (eg, as with thromboprophylaxis).  Subsequent antibody activation of platelets can cause thrombosis; however, thrombosis is more commonly venous than arterial, and arterial thrombosis is not typically bilateral and symmetric.  In addition, symptoms typically develop 5-10 days after heparin exposure.

(Choice D)  Necrotizing infection of myofascia (ie, necrotizing fasciitis) can cause skin color changes (due to underlying soft tissue infection) and systemic toxicity (eg, fever, hypotension).  However, the skin and soft tissue involvement is not typically bilateral and symmetric and would likely be rapidly progressive in the absence of surgical debridement.

(Choice E)  Rupture of atherosclerotic plaques can form cholesterol emboli that may lodge within the distal peripheral vasculature, causing digital ischemia (eg, blue toe syndrome).  However, bilateral and symmetrical involvement would be unusual.

Educational objective:
Vasopressors (eg, norepinephrine), which cause profound vasoconstriction, can also cause ischemia of peripheral structures such as the distal digits.  The resulting digital tissue necrosis is usually bilateral and symmetric.

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 45 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "I fell down some stairs and my chest hurts."
History of Present Illness:

  • slipped and fell backward down half a flight of stairs
  • did not hit her head; no loss of consciousness
  • right-sided chest and back pain

Past Medical History:

  • none

Past Surgical History:

  • cesarean delivery ×2
  • tubal ligation

Medications:

  • none

Allergies:

  • no known drug allergies

Family History:

  • noncontributory

Psychosocial History:

  • no tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substance use
  • married, 2 children
  • works as a paralegal

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
36.8 C
(98.2 F)		88/min24/min138/88
mm Hg		98%
on RA		165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)		70.8 kg
(156 lb)		26 kg/m2
  • Appearance: alert but uncomfortable
  • Pulmonary: shallow and symmetric breaths
  • Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmur
  • Musculoskeletal: right posterior chest wall tenderness to palpation; no crepitus or bony step-offs

Diagnostic Studies

  • Chest x-ray: minimally displaced posterior fracture of right sixth rib; bilateral basilar atelectasis; no pneumothorax or pleural effusion

Question: Which of the following is most essential for preventing pulmonary complications in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has an isolated rib fracture without evidence of chest wall deformity or internal organ injury (eg, pneumothorax).  Even in the absence of concomitant injuries, a rib fracture can cause sufficient pain to result in shallow breathing (ie, small tidal volumes) and atelectasis.  Without adequate pain control, splinting and atelectasis increase the risk of pneumonia, a frequent complication of rib fracture.

After significant associated injuries have been ruled out or treated, the mainstay of rib fracture management is pain control to ensure appropriate ventilation and adequate cough.  Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, ibuprofen, ketorolac) and opioids are commonly used.  Opioids can cause central respiratory depression, but this disadvantage is typically outweighed by the benefits of adequate pain control.  For patients who require hospitalization (eg, those with more extensive rib fractures), intravenous analgesics and regional anesthetic techniques (eg, epidural infusion, intercostal nerve blocks) may be added.  Patients also should be taught the importance of pulmonary hygiene and how to use an incentive spirometer.

(Choice B)  This patient's basilar atelectasis (ie, lower lung collapse) seen on x-ray is likely due to insufficient inspiratory effort secondary to pain; deep breathing (ie, providing adequate inspiratory volume) can reexpand the collapsed lung and resolve the atelectasis.  In contrast, continuous positive airway pressure provides gentle pressure to prevent repetitive upper airway collapse/obstruction (eg, in obstructive sleep apnea); it would not provide enough pressure to reexpand large segments of collapsed lung.

(Choice C)  Inhaled bronchodilators decrease airway resistance and improve airflow for patients with reactive airways (eg, asthma).  This patient exhibits no evidence (eg, wheezing) of reactive airways.

(Choice D)  Percussive chest physiotherapy can loosen thick secretions in the lungs to facilitate removal by coughing.  Although this patient should receive an analgesic to ensure adequate cough, there is no evidence of thick secretions that require percussive physiotherapy; in addition, this technique likely would be extremely painful for a patient with rib fracture.

(Choice E)  Although rib fracture can be complicated by pneumonia, prophylactic antibiotics are not routinely indicated.

(Choice F)  Rib fractures usually heal without operative repair, especially a nondisplaced fracture like this patient has.  Surgical fixation is typically indicated only in severe cases (eg, flail chest with failure to wean from the ventilator, significant chest wall deformity).

Educational objective:
Adequate pain control is the mainstay of rib fracture management to prevent the associated complications of atelectasis and pneumonia.
